page.title: 08Coppicing Chestnut
page.content: About a quarter of Saxonbury Wood is used for coppicing.Sweet chestnut trees are cut down just above the ground and allowed to shoot from the base.In Sussex it takes about fifteen years for the timber to reach a usable size.The trunks are cut down and the base shoots again.The timber is sometimes worked in the woodland.A billhook is used to remove the bark and the chestnut is made into garden fencing or stakes.A tractor is used to take large trunks away.The coppicing in Saxonbury Wood is at several stages.Some has only recently been felled
